title: 111_hr2898
content: The Act titled "Wounded Warrior Caregiver Assistance Act" provides support services for family caregivers. The Act titled "Wounded Warrior Caregiver Assistance Act" provides interactive training sessions for family caregivers and individuals who support them, incorporating telehealth technologies and teaching techniques for caring for disabled veterans, including those with post-traumatic stress disorder. The Act provides support for family caregivers of veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury deployed in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Secretary must record veteran health details and provide information on support services from public, private, and non-profit agencies, collaborating with the Department of Health and Human Services. The Act mandates the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide family caregivers with an Internet-based service containing a directory of county-level services, message boards for peer support, and comprehensive health-related information for disabled veterans. The Secretary is also required to conduct outreach to inform disabled veterans and their families about these services. The Department of Veterans Affairs is mandated to conduct outreach for caregiver support through public service announcements, brochures, Internet-based methods, and a dedicated web page with interactive elements. The term 'aging network' and 'caregiver services' are defined in the Older Americans Act of 1965. A 'family caregiver' is someone who provides noninstitutional extended care to a disabled veteran, whether or not they live with them. Section 1782 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include counseling and mental health services for family caregivers as defined in section 1786. Section 1720B of title 38, United States Code is amended to provide respite care services for family caregivers of veterans, ensuring that the care meets the needs of the veteran and is appropriate for their age.
